üñº "Officer of the Hussars", Kehinde Wiley, oil on canvas, Museum Purchase, Friends of African and African American Art, DIA no. 2008.3.
Wiley's work is found in public and private collections around the world. You can see his painting "Officer of the Hussars," a visitor favorite, at the DIA.
His work challenges the history of Western art, which has largely overlooked or intentionally made invisible black subjects from portraits like this.

Wiley is known for his vibrant, highly naturalistic paintings of contemporary African-American men and women. His subjects are depicted in heroic poses taken from old master paintings whose sitters were typically white men.

In honor of¬†#PrideMonth, we're celebrating the creative contributions of LGBTQIA+ artists in the DIA's collection.
Kehinde Wiley, born in Los Angeles in 1977, is one of the most celebrated painters of his generation. https://t.co/v3RUOKi9Hs

In "Artist's¬†Black¬†Piet√† a Call for Justice", @GrottoNetwork interviewed Sawyer, as part of their #GrottoStories campaign.

Through works like "Piet√†" ‚Äî painted in 2018 ‚Äî artist Tylonn Sawyer calls on our shared humanity and urges us to pay attention to what‚Äôs happening around us and work for change.

üñº "Quilting Time", Romare Bearden, 1986, mosaic tesserae mounted on plywood, DIA no. 1986.41.

The quilt, a well-known visual motif used by Bearden in a number of his artworks, references a time when the quilt- making tradition was employed by enslaved Africans to include coded messages into their quilts to convey information about the Underground Railroad.
Romare Bearden's mosaic "Quilting Time" serves as a powerful symbol of the struggle for freedom.

Although the Emancipation Proclamation had been issued in 1863 during the Civil War, it was at least two years until Confederate surrender in Texas made it possible for enslaved Africans there to celebrate their freedom.

Today is Juneteenth, a holiday celebrated by African Americans to commemorate June 19, 1865, the date slavery ended in the United States when Union soldiers officially informed enslaved Africans in Texas that they were free. https://t.co/k1FFd3OYj9

üñº "James Baldwin in setting sun over Harlem, Harlem, New York", 1979, Ming Smith, gelatin silver print, Museum Purchase, Albert and Peggy DeSalle Charitable Trust, DIA no. 2017.12. #ArtOfRebellion #BlackArtists
This artwork was featured in the DIA's 2017 exhibition, "Art of Rebellion: Black Art of the Civil Rights Movement."

Here, Smith used multiple exposures to combine two different photographs: an image of Baldwin, and one of Harlem, where he grew up. The result is an image of Baldwin hovering over the Harlem skyline like a protective heavenly spirit.

The ethereal image pays homage to the widespread influence of internationally acclaimed writer James Baldwin, whose essays frankly confronted racism while his novels portrayed the struggles, relationships, and dreams of African Americans.

Born in Detroit, artist Ming Smith has photographed many important Black cultural figures, including Alvin Ailey and Nina Simone, throughout her career. She created "James Baldwin in setting sun over Harlem, Harlem, New York" in 1979. https://t.co/pYVwUJgMcO
üñº "The 1920's‚Ä¶ Migrants Arrive and Cast Their Ballots", 1974, Jacob Lawrence, screenprint printed in color on wove paper, DIA no. 76.54. #ArtOfRebellion #BlackArtists
"The 1920's‚Ä¶ Migrants Arrive and Cast Their Ballots" was featured in the DIA's 2017 exhibition, "Art of Rebellion: Black Art of the Civil Rights Movement."
Lawrence is widely known for his 'Migration' series, a collection depicting the movement of African-Americans from the rural South to the urban North between World War I and World War II.
To Lawrence and others, independence meant exercising one‚Äôs right as an American to vote without being subject to intimidation through arbitrary tests, poll taxes, and sometimes violence.
Lawrence combined social realism, bold color, and vivid narrative to show a group of African American migrants from southern states casting their ballots at a polling location in the north.

Artist Jacob Lawrence created "The 1920's‚Ä¶ Migrants Arrive and Cast Their Ballots" in 1974. The artwork illustrates a response to the question, "What does independence mean to you?" for a portfolio meant to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the United States in 1976. https://t.co/UK7BJpFVsK

This artwork was featured in the DIA's 2017 exhibition, "Art of Rebellion: Black Art of the Civil Rights Movement."
üñº "Ancestral Memory",1966, Hale Woodruff, oil on canvas, DIA no. 78.87. #ArtOfRebellion #BlackArtists

Woodruff created ‚ÄúAncestral Memory‚Äù for the exhibition "Art of the American Negro" presented at the First World Festival of Negro Arts held in Dakar, Senegal in 1966. During this time, many African countries were gaining their independence from European colonial rule.
While Woodruff appreciated African art's significance in his heritage, he also recognized the fundamental role it played in the development of modern Western art.

The surrounding shapes derive from African symbols and decorative forms. Through this painting, Woodruff addresses the creative and symbolic legacy of Africa for the history and culture of African Americans.

Artist Hale Woodruff created "Ancestral Memory" in 1966. Here, the central image is a schematic representation of the continent of Africa, rendered in intense red and animated by a human face incorporated into the form. https://t.co/mPrwz0JMy6
Although Catlett had lived and worked in Mexico, her art was highly admired by artists engaged in the Black Arts Movement.
This blending of distinctive characteristics speaks to the enriching potential of diaspora and an inherent human dignity that transcends ethnic and national differences.

While the rounded head shape and high cheekbones resemble those of the colossal stone heads made by the Olmec people of southern Mexico (between 1200 and 400 BCE), the generous features and hair texture evoke a beauty of African descent.
With this sculpture, Catlett experimented with form and emphasis on ethnicity to make statements about the complexity of identity.

Artist Elizabeth Catlett created "Terra-Cotta Head" in 1960. Throughout her career, Catlett's work addressed two compelling issues: social justice and the lives of women. When the DIA is open, ‚ÄúTerra-Cotta Head‚Äù is on view in our African American galleries. https://t.co/HotJUNVXlp
üñº "Queen Mother Helen Moore", 2015, Mario Moore, oil on copper, DIA no. 2017.51. #ArtOfRebellion #BlackArtists

This intimate portrait ‚Äî symbolizing the protection and power provided by the women in Moore's family ‚Äî depicts his grandmother Helen Moore, a Detroit education activist, proudly displaying framed photographs of men in her family.

Artist Mario Moore created "Queen Mother Helen Moore" in 2015. This artwork was featured in the DIA's 2017 exhibition, "Art of Rebellion: Black Art of the Civil Rights Movement." https://t.co/nHBeinSdmH

üñº "Revolutionary", 1972, Wadsworth Jarrell, screenprint printed in color on white wove paper, Gift of the Azzi/Lusenhop Black Arts Movement Collection. #ArtOfRebellion #BlackArtists
The bright colors and bold lettering Jarrell uses in "Revolutionary" are signature elements used by artists who worked in the Collective.
His work became distinguishable for its provocative and vibrant character, as well as for the artist's loyalty to African symbolism and geometric patterns.
Wadsworth Jarrell is a founding member of AfriCOBRA ‚Äî a collective of African American artists formed in Chicago in 1968 as a response to the Civil Rights Movement.

Jarrell depicts Davis wearing a ‚ÄòRevolutionary Suit‚Äô designed by his spouse, Jae Jarrell, an African American artist known for her fashion designs and her involvement with the Black Arts Movement of the 1960s.

Words from her speeches ‚Äî including "STRUGGLE", "RESIST", "BLACK", and "BEAUTIFUL" ‚Äî swirl around her and emanate from her hair. "Revolutionary" was featured in the DIA's 2017 exhibition, "Art of Rebellion: Black Art of the Civil Rights Movement."

Artist Wadsworth Jarrell created "Revolutionary" in 1972. This portrait depicts African American political activist, writer, and scholar Angela Davis who became widely known known during the Civil Rights Movement. https://t.co/soKZUztd67

Lifelong Detroiters and collectors with eclectic interests for over a decade, Joann was retired from the medical field and Harold from a natural gas supplier. Harold co-founded the Detroit Fine Arts Breakfast Club, a weekly convening of artists and collectors.
